examples.en: They say "evil begets evil" right? So they just got properly punished.
examples.ja: 悪因悪果って言うだろ？当然のむくいだよ。

examples.en: If you do something bad, you'll get in trouble later because evil breeds evil.
examples.ja: 悪いことをしたら、悪因悪果で後々ひどい目にあうよ。

examples.en: What does the Bible say about karma? Was it like "evil begets evil" or something?
examples.ja: 聖書には、業について何て書いてあるんだっけ？悪因悪果とかだっけか？

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>evil</kanji> <kanji>cause</kanji> yields the <kanji>evil</kanji> <kanji>fruit</kanji>, or more simply, <vocabulary>evil breeds evil</vocabulary>.

This is a Buddhist term, often used together with 善因善果 (virtue breeds virtue) to illustrate the concept of karma. While not a widely known phrase, it a nice saying to remind us of the importance of our actions.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The last 悪果 gets the 悪 shortened a little bit.

examples.en: This is designed to form an scalene triangle when viewed from above.
examples.ja: これは上から見ると不等辺三角形になるようにデザインされています。

examples.en: At this time, the following inequality holds.
examples.ja: この時、以下の不等式が成り立ちます。

examples.en: The car is designed to distribute torque unequally at 41:59 between the front and the rear.
examples.ja: この車は、トルクが前41：後59で不等配分されるようになっています。

meaning_mnemonic: When something is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>equal</kanji> is of course <vocabulary>unequal</vocabulary>. It's an <vocabulary>inequality</vocabulary>. You'll usually see this word in technical contexts like math and engineering, but it does pop up in more general formal writing, too.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My stepfather used to give me piggyback rides all the time when I was little.
examples.ja: 小さい頃、継父にいつもおんぶをしてもらっていました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>father</kanji> you've <kanji>inherit</kanji>ed isn't your original father, he's your <vocabulary>stepfather</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This word can also be read as ままちち, because 継 can take the special reading まま when it's used as the prefix "step," as in "stepfather."

examples.en: Show him what kind of champion you are!
examples.ja: そいつにチャンピオンの面目躍如たるところを見せつけてやれ！

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>leap</kanji> of <kanji>likeness</kanji> is when something that's not real takes a big leap towards the likeness to reality. This happens when something is <vocabulary>vividly depicted</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>clearly expressed</vocabulary>.

This word is generally used in the phrase 面目躍如たる, which functions as an adjective to exemplify someone’s honor.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Take this too, if you want.
examples.ja: よかったら之も持って行きなさい。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Note that this is almost always written in kana in modern Japanese.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: Before my period I always get violent emotional ups and downs.
examples.ja: 生理前はどうしても感情の起伏が激しくなってしまう。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Wake up</kanji>, now <kanji>lay</kanji> yourself down, now wake up again, okay now lay again. What you're doing is called <vocabulary>undulation</vocabulary>. If your emotions do it it's called <vocabulary>ups and downs</vocabulary>. Everyone goes through stuff like this sometimes.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Why have you not been telling us that your brother is a criminal?
examples.ja: どうして弟が犯罪者であることを伏せていたんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bow</kanji> or <kanji>lay</kanji>, so the verb version is what when you try <vocabulary>to cover</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to hide</vocabulary> something. You're doing the action to something, you're not the one hiding.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Who's that you're trying <vocabulary>to cover</vocabulary> up? It's your <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ) brother. He keeps doing embarrassing things and trying to get you in trouble. So you're trying <vocabulary>to hide</vocabulary> him with your jacket. Well we see him, we know he's a fool, so you can stop now.

examples.en: I'll definitely make them surrender.
examples.ja: 絶対にあいつらを降伏させてみせる。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Bow</kanji> as you <kanji>descend</kanji> into enemy territory. This is how you have to <vocabulary>surrender</vocabulary> if you want to live. Keep your head nice and low and descend into their ranks.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We conducted an undercover investigation of the mafia.
examples.ja: 我々はマフィアの潜伏捜査をすることになった。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Bow</kanji> your head to <kanji>conceal</kanji> yourself better than you were <vocabulary>conceal</vocabulary>ing yourself before. If you want to go into <vocabulary>hiding</vocabulary> you need to know how to lay low!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This method of foreshadowing is amazing.
examples.ja: 伏線の張り方がすごい。

meaning_mnemonic: Connect a bunch of things <kanji>lay</kanji>ing in a <kanji>line</kanji>. Something's happening here. You can't put your finger on it, but you're pretty sure this is <vocabulary>foreshadowing</vocabulary> for something else.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: They were attacked by an ambush.
examples.ja: 伏兵に襲われたんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>soldier</kanji> only <kanji>lay</kanji>s herself down when she's about to <vocabulary>ambush</vocabulary> the enemy! If you see some soldiers laying around, it's not that they're lazy, it's because they're getting ready to pounce!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The picture I drew was chosen as a good piece of work.
examples.ja: 私の描いた絵が佳作で入選しました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Make</kanji> something <kanji>excellent</kanji> and everyone will call it a <vocabulary>fine work</vocabulary>. Or make something that sucks and let everyone down. It's your call.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I'll always be by your side.
examples.ja: いつまでも君の傍にいるよ。

examples.en: I couldn't understand it even when I was watching from close by.
examples.ja: 傍から見ていても全然わからなかった。

examples.en: If it's my husband you're looking for, he's out drinking at an izakaya near the Keio Department Store right now.
examples.ja: 旦那なら、今京王百貨店の傍の居酒屋に飲みに行っているよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Something <kanji>nearby</kanji> is <vocabulary>near</vocabulary> to you. It's very <vocabulary>close</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: 

There is a restaurant <vocabulary>near</vocabulary> your house that only sells dishes with <reading>soba</reading> (そば) noodles in them. They're delicious, but it's so <vocabulary>close</vocabulary> to your home that you can smell them all the time. Sometimes it feels like that's all you'll ever smell anymore.

examples.en: I only looked on at the bullying.
examples.ja: 私はイジメをただ傍観していました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Nearby</kanji> there is a beautiful <kanji>view</kanji>. <vocabulary>Look on</vocabulary> as the sun sets and the sky changes color. You would give up anything to be able to <vocabulary>spectate</vocabulary> this kind of thing all the time.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The police may perform correspondence monitoring for the sake of the criminal investigation.
examples.ja: 警察は、犯罪捜査のために、通信の傍受を行うことがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: Only <kanji>accept</kanji> new people moving in <kanji>nearby</kanji> once you've finished properly <vocabulary>monitoring</vocabulary> them! <vocabulary>Tapping</vocabulary> into their phones will probably help too, but don't tell anyone I told you to do that.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When the jam I boiled cools it will become viscous and solidify into jelly.
examples.ja: 煮詰めたジャムは、冷めてくると粘性が強まり、ゼリー状に凝固します。

meaning_mnemonic: Your pudding <kanji>congeal</kanji>ed and is all <kanji>hard</kanji>. How on earth did it <vocabulary>solidify</vocabulary> like this? It shouldn't <vocabulary>freeze</vocabulary> unless you put it in the freezer. Unless, did you? Oh...
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: She was my type of woman so I stared unintentionally.
examples.ja: タイプの女性がいたので、思わず凝視してしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Freeze</kanji> and <kanji>look at</kanji> me. Your <vocabulary>stare</vocabulary> is giving me the creeps! You can move now. Hey. You can move now. Stop I said!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It's inevitable for your shoulders and neck to grow stiff from desk work.
examples.ja: デスクワークのせいで肩や首が凝るのは仕方がない。

examples.en: I've been into haiku these days.
examples.ja: 最近、俳句に凝っているんですよ。

examples.en: My wife's plating of food is always elaborate.
examples.ja: 妻の料理の盛り付けは、いつも凝っています。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>congeal</kanji> or <kanji>freeze</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to grow stiff</vocabulary>. Remember 肩こり (shoulder stiffness)? This is where that こり part comes from.

凝る also means  <vocabulary>to be passionate about</vocabulary> something. Think of it this way: your passions are <kanji>freez</kanji>ing onto one thing, so you're going <vocabulary>to be into</vocabulary> that thing.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

What have all your friends started <vocabulary>to be passionate about</vocabulary>? Their <reading>子</reading>s (こ). They all keep having kids and now that's all they seem to care about. Damn kids.

examples.en: This summer vacation I volunteered at a senior citizen’s home.
examples.ja: 今年の夏休みは、老人ホームで奉仕活動をしました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Dedicate</kanji> yourself to <kanji>doing</kanji> the best at school by having perfect <vocabulary>attendance</vocabulary>! That's how you can show you're really dedicated to learning.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I think all Japanese citizens should believe in Shinto.
examples.ja: 私は日本国民全員が神道を信奉すべきだと思います。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Dedicate</kanji> your life to what you <kanji>believe</kanji> in and you'll have really strong <vocabulary>belief</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>faith</vocabulary> in whatever that thing is. Just try to dedicate yourself to something nice.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Oreiboukou, which means "free service after finishing an apprenticeship," is a system for nurses to pay back the student loans they took out while they were at school.
examples.ja: お礼奉公とは看護婦が、看護学生時代に借りた奨学金の返済制度の一つです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Dedicate</kanji> yourself to the <kanji>public</kanji> by doing community <vocabulary>service</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Why did the Prime Minister receive criticism for making an offering at Yasukuni Shrine?
examples.ja: どうして首相が靖国神社に玉串料を奉納することが批判されるのですか。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>dedicate</kanji> your entire <kanji>supply</kanji> of food to the gods it's called an <vocabulary>offering</vocabulary>, and it takes real <vocabulary>dedication</vocabulary> to do something like that.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I took a urinalysis test at the hospital and it said I was pregnant.
examples.ja: 病院で尿検査をして、妊娠していると言われました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: The beginning of the Yayoi Period was approximately 300 BCE.
examples.ja: 弥生時代のはじまりは紀元前300年頃です。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Life</kanji> in Japan was <kanji>increasing</kanji> at its fastest rate during the <vocabulary>Yayoi Period</vocabulary>. It's one of the earliest periods of history in Japan that we know about! You should look it up, if you don't already know about it.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is an exception but it's the same in Japanese as it is in English. So if you just remember it's <reading>Yayoi</reading> (やよい) in English, you'll remember the Japanese too!

examples.en: There are two types of paths for blood circulation.
examples.ja: 血液の循環には二種類の経路があります。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Circulation</kanji> in a <kanji>loop</kanji> is still <vocabulary>circulation</vocabulary>. Or <vocabulary>rotation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I expressed my condolences and prayed silently.
examples.ja: 哀悼の意を表して、黙祷しました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Grieve</kanji> for a <kanji>pathetic</kanji> situation by offering your <vocabulary>condolence</vocabulary>s. Showing <vocabulary>regret</vocabulary> is the best way to handle it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: How about we all hold a memorial concert for him?
examples.ja: みんなで奴の追悼コンサートを開かないか？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Follow</kanji> people who <kanji>grieve</kanji> by <vocabulary>mourning</vocabulary> with them. You don't want to be the only one who doesn't seem sad.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned this reading with the word 追随, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case:

You're <vocabulary>mourning</vocabulary> the loss of your pet bird. You can't help but yell <reading>TWEE</reading>T (つい) to the sky, hoping she'll come back to life. It doesn't work so you stay in a state of mourning for the rest of your life. She was your best bird friend, after all.

examples.en: You wouldn’t spare even a little time so all your plans fell through!
examples.ja: お前がちょっとした手間を惜しんだために、全ての計画がおじゃんになったんだぞ！

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>frugal</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to be frugal</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be sparing</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You should try <vocabulary>to be frugal</vocabulary> when you go to the <reading>ocea</reading>n (おし). There are lots of things to buy, like delicious food, sun hats, and tofugu dolls, but you really shouldn't spend all your money there. Try to plan on spending less when you head to the ocean next time, okay?

examples.en: Our school missed getting into the top eight by losing a close game.
examples.ja: わが校は、惜敗でベスト8入りを逃しました。

meaning_mnemonic: Your team was about to win the game but you decided to be <kanji>frugal</kanji> with your shots near the end and it resulted in <kanji>defeat</kanji>, making it a <vocabulary>loss of a close game</vocabulary>. If you had just taken those shots your team probably would have won. What a <vocabulary>regrettable defeat</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: A long time ago, a young murderer said, "I can’t help but find murder pleasant."
examples.ja: 昔、「僕は殺しが愉快でたまらない」と言った少年殺人犯がいました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>pleasant</kanji> <kanji>pleasant</kanji> person is super <vocabulary>pleasant</vocabulary>! They're <vocabulary>happy</vocabulary> and nice to everybody all the time!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Working at a company is depressing.
examples.ja: 会社へ出勤するのが憂鬱です。

meaning_mnemonic: With lots of <kanji>grief</kanji> and <kanji>gloom</kanji> in your life you'll probably end up in a spiral of <vocabulary>depression</vocabulary>. Don't worry, you'll be okay. Things get better with time so don't give into the <vocabulary>gloom</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Young warriors of patriotism, now is the time to stand up!
examples.ja: 憂国の若きサムライたちよ、今こそ立ち上がれ！

meaning_mnemonic: Whenever something bad happens to your <kanji>country</kanji> you feel an exceptional amount of <kanji>grief</kanji> for your fellow country people. This is some serious <vocabulary>patriotic concern</vocabulary> you've got going on. Let's hope you use those concerns for something good and don't get too carried away.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: What is the company president concerned about now?
examples.ja: ズバリ、社長が現在抱える憂慮とは何ですか。

meaning_mnemonic: All you can do is <kanji>consider</kanji> your <kanji>grief</kanji> and how it's ruining your life. That's called <vocabulary>anxiety</vocabulary>, and it can be a real problem. You end up being <vocabulary>concern</vocabulary>ed about everything, but don't worry. There are ways to combat it. You'll be okay!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It’s natural for parents to be anxious about their children’s’ futures.
examples.ja: 親が子供の将来を憂えるのは当然のことだ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>grieve</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to grieve</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be anxious</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Your aunt starts <vocabulary>to grieve</vocabulary> really loudly at your Uncle Ray's funeral. "<reading>Ooh, Ray</reading> (うれ)! OOoh, Ray why did you have to leave me!" It's really sad. You even hear it in your head after you've left and gone home. You've never seen someone start <vocabulary>to be distressed</vocabulary> like that in public.

examples.en: The trial ended with an absolutely unsatisfactory result.
examples.ja: 裁判は誠に遺憾な結果に終わりました。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>leave behind</kanji> something and it makes you feel <kanji>remorse</kanji> it's a really <vocabulary>regrettable</vocabulary> situation. You should probably go back for whatever it was so you won't lead an <vocabulary>unsatisfactory</vocabulary> life.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please teach me manners for when I attend my friend’s wedding reception.
examples.ja: 友人の披露宴に出席する際のマナーを教えてください。

meaning_mnemonic: You already learned that 披露 means "announcement" or "display," so add a <kanji>banquet</kanji> to that and you're at a <vocabulary>wedding reception</vocabulary>! Or if no one's getting married but they're showing off something at a big place with food and stuff it's a just a normal <vocabulary>reception</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: For a moment I felt a little anxious.
examples.ja: 一抹の不安が胸をよぎった。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Erase</kanji> <kanji>one</kanji> part of your feelings and you'll only feel <vocabulary>a little</vocabulary> bit of them.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: All the minister did that day was kill off the petition.
examples.ja: この日大臣がしていたことは、陳情の抹殺ばかりだった。

examples.en: Obliteration of the villagers is our objective.
examples.ja: 村民の抹殺が我々の目標だ。

examples.en: That man rose against the system and was erased from society.
examples.ja: あの男は、組織に歯向かったため、社会から抹殺されたんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>erase</kanji> or <kanji>kill</kanji> something results in total <vocabulary>obliteration</vocabulary>. This word refers to the <vocabulary>erasure</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>denial</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>ignoring</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>killing</vocabulary> of something's very existence. It can even mean <vocabulary>murder</vocabulary> in some cases.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I drink a matcha latte every morning.
examples.ja: 毎朝抹茶ラテを飲んでいます。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Erase</kanji> your need for normal <kanji>tea</kanji> by drinking <vocabulary>matcha</vocabulary>. It is far superior to all others and you'll never turn back once you've had a taste.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: His army registration was deleted due to the injury.
examples.ja: 彼は怪我で一軍登録を抹消されたんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <kanji>erase</kanji> and <kanji>extinguish</kanji> every lamp and every picture of a lamp in the world, just <vocabulary>erase</vocabulary> them all. Simple as that.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m planning to install cupboards here.
examples.ja: ここに戸棚を据え付けるつもりだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 据える, meaning "to install," and 付ける, meaning "to attach." Put them together and you're still going <vocabulary>to install</vocabulary> something or <vocabulary>to equip</vocabulary> something. There's just more hands on work happening.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Will you forget that conversation for a moment?
examples.ja: この話は一旦なかったことにしてもらえませんか。

meaning_mnemonic: You only have time to do <kanji>one</kanji> thing at <kanji>dawn</kanji> <vocabulary>once</vocabulary>. Dawn is really short so you can do whatever it is <vocabulary>for a moment</vocabulary>, but that's it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m going to visit a shrine with my family on New Year’s Day.
examples.ja: 元旦には家族で初詣に行きます。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>origin</kanji> of <kanji>dawn</kanji> can be found on <vocabulary>New Year's Day</vocabulary>. That's when the new sun is born and rises above the earth for a whole year until it dies. And that's the origin of dawn, children. Don't let your teachers tell you otherwise.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 元 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who's always there on the dawn of <vocabulary>New Year's Day</vocabulary> welcoming the new sun? <reading>Gan</reading>dhi (がん). He sits on the edge of the earth and makes sure the sun feels welcome. What a nice guy.

examples.en: I went to pray at a Shinto shrine in order for the company to prosper.
examples.ja: 商売が繁昌するように、神社でお祈りをしてきました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Overgrown</kanji> <kanji>prosperity</kanji> is still <vocabulary>prosperity</vocabulary>. Why, it's even <vocabulary>thriving</vocabulary>. Nice!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for the rendaku that changes しょう to じょう!

examples.en: I'll respond to everyone’s simple questions.
examples.ja: みなさんの素朴な疑問にお答えします。

meaning_mnemonic: People made from <kanji>simple</kanji> <kanji>element</kanji>s are also pretty <vocabulary>simple</vocabulary>. And they can be <vocabulary>naive</vocabulary> too. But that's just how they're built.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Are you from Tochigi Prefecture?
examples.ja: 栃木県の出身なんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>prefecture</kanji> with lots of <kanji>horse chestnut</kanji> <kanji>tree</kanji>s is <vocabulary>Tochigi prefecture</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word consists of the kun'yomi readings for 栃 and 木 and the on'yomi for 県, like most with prefectures. As long as you remember that き is changed to ぎ here, you should be able to remember this reading easily!

examples.en: If you don’t have a bottle opener, I know a trick to open a beer bottle.
examples.ja: 栓抜きが無くても瓶ビールの栓を抜く裏ワザを知っています。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: The bottle opener is in that drawer.
examples.ja: 栓抜きはそこの引き出しに入ってます。

meaning_mnemonic: What do you use to <kanji>pull out</kanji> a <kanji>cork</kanji>? A <vocabulary>bottle opener</vocabulary>! Or a <vocabulary>corkscrew</vocabulary> if you're feeling adventurous.
reading_mnemonic: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 栓 and the kun'yomi reading for 抜, which you learned with 抜く. If you can remember that, you'll be able to remember this too!

examples.en: If you're looking for detergent, it's under the sink.
examples.ja: 洗浄剤なら、シンクの下にあります。

meaning_mnemonic: You already learned that the word 洗浄 means "washing." So when you're washing the laundry you have to use just the right <kanji>dose</kanji> of <vocabulary>detergent</vocabulary> to make sure they wash properly. If you use too little detergent they'll still smell, but if you use too much detergent the washer will explode with bubbles! Just be careful okay, don't end up like me.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Mom makes the best pumpkin pie!
examples.ja: お母さんが作る南瓜パイは絶品なんだ！

examples.en: Today is winter solstice, so let's have a something with kabocha in for dinner.
examples.ja: 今日は冬至だから晩御飯は南瓜を使った料理にしよう。

examples.en: I cooked a boiled squash dish.
examples.ja: 南瓜の煮物を炊きました。

meaning_mnemonic:
In the <kanji>south</kanji>, a <kanji>melon</kanji> grows all lumpy and orange because of the hot sun, or sometimes orange and green. Wait, that's not a melon, it's a <vocabulary>pumpkin</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>squash</vocabulary>! 

南瓜 often refers to any kind of squash, including Halloween pumpkins. But in everyday Japanese, it usually means a kind of Japanese squash that's green on the outside and orange inside, called <vocabulary>kabocha</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for this is an exception, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

A Japanese <vocabulary>pumpkin</vocabulary> doesn't taste like American pumpkins. It tastes more like <reading>can</reading>ned <reading>bo</reading>iled <reading>cho</reading>colate (かぼちゃ). Oh, you're not familiar with that flavor? Well, try a Japanese pumpkin and you'll know what it tastes like. 

This word is also sometimes read なんきん, especially in the east of Japan.

examples.en: I’m looking for a woman who has an atmosphere with classic features.
examples.ja: 瓜実顔で雰囲気のある女優を探しています。

meaning_mnemonic: If you ask me to tell the <kanji>truth</kanji> I'll say your <kanji>face</kanji> is shaped like a <kanji>melon</kanji>. No no, it's not a bad thing! You just have a really <vocabulary>oval face</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
This word consists of the kun'yomi readings for 瓜 and 顔, but in the middle there, 実 has a bit of an exceptional reading. You certainly haven't learned this weirdness before, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You know who has an <vocabulary>oval face</vocabulary>? <reading>Zayn</reading> (ざね) formerly from One Direction. When you think of handsome oval faces, picture Zayn's.

examples.en: Cavities don’t just spontaneously heal.
examples.ja: 虫歯が自然治癒することはありません。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>healing</kanji> <kanji>cure</kanji> will be great for <vocabulary>healing</vocabulary> sick people.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Were the risks of adhesion after surgery explained accurately to you?
examples.ja: 手術後の癒着リスクについて、きちんと説明はなされましたか。

meaning_mnemonic: What do you <kanji>wear</kanji> to <kanji>heal</kanji> a really serious injury? An <vocabulary>adhesion</vocabulary>. Okay, so you don't actually wear these, but your body makes them for your insides to wear so you can heal. Nice job insides!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: She’s never treated another person rudely.
examples.ja: 彼女は、決して他人に対して粗野に振る舞うことがなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: Your home is out in the middle of a <kanji>coarse</kanji> looking <kanji>field</kanji>. Whenever you bring friends over the only word they say to describe your dirt and grass home is that it's <vocabulary>rustic</vocabulary>. That's pretty <vocabulary>rude</vocabulary> of them, you love your dirt home! Even if it is kinda small and stinky and in a field.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I always use the coarse flour from corn, wheat, or beans in my smoothies.
examples.ja: 私はいつも、トウモロコシ、麦、豆などをひき割って粗い粉にしたものをスムージーに入れます。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>coarse</kanji>? <vocabulary>Coarse</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rough</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The most <vocabulary>coarse</vocabulary> thing you can think of is <reading>a ro</reading>ck (あら). You rubbed it on your face and it was really <vocabulary>rough</vocabulary> and kinda painful. You probably shouldn't be rubbing a rock on your face, actually.

examples.en: Crude gasoline will shorten a car’s lifespan.
examples.ja: 粗悪なガソリンは、車の寿命を早める。

meaning_mnemonic: If it's <kanji>coarse</kanji> in a <kanji>bad</kanji> way it's still <vocabulary>coarse</vocabulary> but it's also <vocabulary>crude</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>inferior</vocabulary>. You don't want a fuzzy sweater to be coarse, do you? Or a carpet? If they are, they're this kind of coarse.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I update the total download rankings for popular apps everyday on this site.
examples.ja: このサイトでは、人気アプリの累計ダウンロードランキングを毎日更新しています。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Measure</kanji> how much you've <kanji>accumulate</kanji>d and you'll have a <vocabulary>cumulative total</vocabulary>. That total includes all the things you've bought since the beginning of time. Probably.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: He was promoted to section head at a very young age.
examples.ja: 彼は若くして部長に累進した。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Accumulate</kanji> enough of a good reputation at your company in <kanji>advance</kanji> and you'll be able to have <vocabulary>successive promotion</vocabulary>s. You'll be boss in no time!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: How do you think the Japanese government accumulated such a great amount of national debt?
examples.ja: 日本政府が巨額の国債を累積していることについて、あなたはどのようにお考えですか。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Accumulate</kanji> and <kanji>accumulate</kanji> make <vocabulary>accumulation</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: They naturally showed the old shop’s spirit.
examples.ja: 彼らは、まさに老舗の意地を見せたんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>elderly</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is an <vocabulary>old shop</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This reading is an exception, so here's a mnemonic:

You go to an <vocabulary>old shop</vocabulary> and come across a <reading>shee</reading>p <reading>knee</reading> <reading>sa</reading>le (しにせ). When you ask what a sheep knee sale is, the clerk tells you quite matter-of-factly that it's a sale on all the sheep knees. You've never seen this in newer shops, so it must be a pretty old practice to buy and sell sheep knees.

examples.en: Of course, freshly shaven wasabi is delicious.
examples.ja: やはり、すりたての山葵は美味しいね。

meaning_mnemonic: If you dig up <kanji>hollyhock</kanji>s in the <kanji>mountain</kanji>s, and grind up their roots, you'll have <vocabulary>wasabi</vocabulary>! Don't eat too much, or you'll burn your tongue off.
reading_mnemonic: This reading is an exception, but I'm sure (at least I hope) that you've heard the word wasabi before. It's the same in Japanese so just remember the meaning and you'll know the reading too!

examples.en: We're in trouble. A POW has escaped!
examples.ja: 大変だ。捕虜が脱走したぞ！

examples.en: In the Pacific War, about 130,000 American soldiers were taken as prisoners of war in Japan.
examples.ja: 太平洋戦争では、 約13万人もの米兵が日本の捕虜となった。

examples.en: In exchange for our soldiers, we released 10 enemy prisoners of war.
examples.ja: 我が国の兵と引き換えに、敵国の捕虜１０人を解放した。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Catch</kanji> a <kanji>captive</kanji> and he'll be a <vocabulary>prisoner of war</vocabulary>. Or, if you're not in a war, just an ordinary <vocabulary>captive</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: She writes on her blog everyday about techniques to captivate men.
examples.ja: 彼女は、毎日ブログで男を虜にするテクニックについて書いています。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

The worst thing to see as a <vocabulary>captive</vocabulary> is a <reading>鳥子</reading> (とりこ), a bird child. Imagine seeing a baby bird held captive in a cage. So sad!

examples.en: Does this merchandise correspond with the target of the campaign?
examples.ja: この商品も、キャンペーンの対象に該当しますか？

meaning_mnemonic: If <kanji>the above</kanji> is <kanji>correct</kanji> then please sign the <vocabulary>correspond</vocabulary>ing line to agree with it. And make sure you correspond in a timely manner.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When the company president went to welcome a distinguished foreign visitor, I attended as an interpreter.
examples.ja: 社長が外国の貴賓を接待する際に、通訳として同行しました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>valuable</kanji> <kanji>VIP</kanji> is a <vocabulary>noble visitor</vocabulary>. They're probably a queen or a diplomat or something. So you better treat them really well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The American President visited Japan as a state guest.
examples.ja: アメリカ大統領が国賓として来日しました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>VIP</kanji> from another <kanji>country</kanji> is a <vocabulary>state guest</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We’d like to thank everyone, including the guests, for honoring us with your presence while you’re all busy.
examples.ja: 来賓の方々をはじめ、皆様にはお忙しい中、ご臨席を賜り誠にありがとうございます。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>VIP</kanji> <kanji>come</kanji>s to your door. They're your <vocabulary>guest</vocabulary>! I hope you aren't going to make them sleep in the couch.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We welcomed the foreign guest of honor with first class Japanese cuisine.
examples.ja: 海外の賓客を一流の和食でもてなしました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>VIP</kanji> <kanji>guest</kanji> is a <vocabulary>guest of honor</vocabulary>. They're even more important than a normal guest.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I am about to be posted to China.
examples.ja: 今度、中国に赴任することになりました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Proceed</kanji> to a new place to do your <kanji>duty</kanji>. That's just a fancy way to say you're about to <vocabulary>move for a different job</vocabulary>. This is usually a job at the same company you're already at, it's just a different position for you.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The master will be away all week.
examples.ja: 旦那は出張で今週ずっと留守にしています。

meaning_mnemonic: At <kanji>dawn</kanji> <kanji>what</kanji>'s the first thing you're supposed to see? Your <vocabulary>master</vocabulary>. He wants you to wake him up and bring his slippers.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The outline grew hazy from my tears.
examples.ja: 涙で輪郭が霞んで見えました。

meaning_mnemonic: Trace the <kanji>enclosure</kanji> of a <kanji>wheel</kanji> on paper and you'll have drawn its <vocabulary>outline</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The police suppressed the demonstrators by the third day.
examples.ja: 警察が三日がかりでデモ隊を鎮圧しました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Tranquilize</kanji> <kanji>pressure</kanji> with medication that helps with its <vocabulary>suppression</vocabulary>. Then you won't have to feel it anymore.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The Star Festival is a ritual to pray for peace and give repose to people killed in the war.
examples.ja: 星祭りは、平和を祈り、戦死者を鎮魂する儀式です。

examples.en: This is a pedestal specially set up for the repose of the souls of the dead.
examples.ja: これは死者の鎮魂のために特別に設けられた台座です。

examples.en: Come on, let's sing a requiem together.
examples.ja: さあ、みんなで鎮魂歌を歌いましょう。

meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>tranquilize</kanji> <kanji>soul</kanji>s you have to a have a mass <vocabulary>repose of souls</vocabulary>. Then their souls will move on to the next life and stop hanging around here, haunting umbrellas.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: In order to appease the god’s anger we need to offer a sacrifice.
examples.ja: 神の怒りを鎮めるには、生贄を捧げる必要があります。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>tranquilize</kanji>, so the verb version is what happens when you've already been able to tranquilize someone. It's <vocabulary>to appease</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to suppress</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You want <vocabulary>to appease</vocabulary> her because <reading>she's</reading> (しず) SUPER mad. She's pissed and she's angry and she's going to beat you up if you don't find out how <vocabulary>to calm</vocabulary> her down!

examples.en: That company ushered in leaders of industry one after another to their staff.
examples.ja: 彼の会社は、業界の重鎮達を次々と役員に迎え入れた。

meaning_mnemonic: You’ll need a <kanji>heavy</kanji> dose to <kanji>tranquilize</kanji> yourself enough to be a <vocabulary>leader</vocabulary>. It can pretty stressful to be a leader so most of them are sedated. Tranquilize yourself too and you'll be just like them!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I received a shot of the painkiller from the doctor.
examples.ja: 医者に鎮痛剤を注射してもらいました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Tranquilize</kanji> your <kanji>pain</kanji> with a strong <kanji>dose</kanji> of <vocabulary>painkiller</vocabulary>s! Yum yum. Don't take too many though!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I registered at the bone marrow bank.
examples.ja: 骨髄バンクに登録しました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Bone</kanji> <kanji>marrow</kanji> is <vocabulary>bone marrow</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I think the essence of Kyoto cooking is in eel dishes.
examples.ja: 京料理の真髄はハモ料理だと思います。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>marrow</kanji> of <kanji>reality</kanji> is the true <vocabulary>essence</vocabulary> of life. If you look deep down into reality you might even find the <vocabulary>true meaning</vocabulary> of life! Hmm I wonder what that is... it probably has something to do with a certain two digit number. Oh well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: He was able to show me the true meaning of being a professional.
examples.ja: プロの神髄を見せつけられました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>marrow</kanji> of a <kanji>god</kanji> contains their <vocabulary>essence</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>spirit</vocabulary>. I don't know how you found that out, it was probably really dangerous. You shouldn't mess with gods.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My spinal cord was damaged in the accident.
examples.ja: 事故で脊髄に傷がついてしまったのです。

meaning_mnemonic:
A person of great <kanji>stature</kanji> probably has a lot of <kanji>marrow</kanji> around their <vocabulary>spinal cord</vocabulary>. (Tall stature = longer spinal cord, after all.)

Be careful with this one — it actually has nothing to do with the bone marrow in your spine, and everything to do with your spinal cord. You know, that nerve superhighway protected by your spine's vertebrae? That thing. They just called it marrow in the old days because it was something soft they found inside the spine.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Of course we have that product in our store.
examples.ja: その商品なら、うちの店にも勿論ありますよ。

examples.en: Of course I want to be able to speak Japanese, but I also want to be able to speak French.
examples.ja: 日本語も勿論ですが、フランス語も喋れるようになりたいです。

examples.en: Needless to say, there are people who can study in between looking after children, but it's difficult for me.
examples.ja: 勿論、子育ての合間に勉強が出来る人もいるだろうけど、私には難しいです。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>must not</kanji> consider this a <kanji>theory</kanji>, because <vocabulary>of course</vocabulary> it's a fact. <vocabulary>Needless to say</vocabulary>, this is the way things are.

This word is often written in kana, but it's worth knowing the kanji version too.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. <vocabulary>Needless to say</vocabulary>, you should be able to read this on your own!

examples.en: Do your best, Eito.
examples.ja: 頑張れよ、瑛斗。

examples.en: The pro athlete Eito Tanaka is over there!
examples.ja: あそこに田中瑛斗選手がいるよ！

examples.en: Singer-songwriter Eito rose to fame on social media.
examples.ja: シンガーソングライターの瑛斗は、ソーシャルメディアで有名になりました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>crystal</kanji> <kanji>ladle</kanji> is the Japanese given name <vocabulary>Eito</vocabulary>. If you know the singer-songwriter Eito, imagine him holding a crystal ladle. If not, any Eito will do! Other public figures with the name include pro baseball player Tanaka Eito (田中 瑛斗) and Takarazuka actor Namiki Eito (波輝 瑛斗).
reading_mnemonic:
This name uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned both these readings with the kanji. Get yourself a crystal ladle to celebrate!

Note: This name can also sometimes be read あきと, as is the case for pro baseball player Takabe Akito (髙部 瑛斗).

examples.en: This morning, Ryota-kun appeared in my dream.
examples.ja: 今朝、夢に遼太君が現れた。

examples.en: I heard that Ryota and Ayano are dating.
examples.ja: 遼太と綾乃ちゃん、付き合ってるらしいよ。

examples.en: Ryota, wake up quickly or you'll be late!
examples.ja: 遼太、早く起きないと遅刻するよ！

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Distant</kanji> <kanji>fat</kanji> makes up the Japanese given name <vocabulary>Ryota</vocabulary>. Imagine soccer player Noguchi Ryota (野口 遼太) kicking a fat soccer ball into the distance while voice actor Asari Ryota (浅利 遼太) commentates.
reading_mnemonic:
This name uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You haven't learned this particular on'yomi for 太 yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Ryota</vocabulary>'s diet consists only of <reading>ta</reading>cos (た). Tacos, tacos, tacos for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Yum!

examples.en: My absolute favorite is pufferfish karaage.
examples.ja: 私の大好物はフグの唐揚げです。

examples.en: I ordered three servings of karaage.
examples.ja: 唐揚げを三人前頼みました。

examples.en: When you have an uncontrollable craving for karaage, it's because you might be low on potassium, so eating a banana is a good idea.
examples.ja: 唐揚げが無性に食べたい時は、カリウム不足なので、バナナを食べるといいですよ。

examples.en: Tempura, karaage, and tatsutaage are all dishes where ingredients are coated in batter and deep-fried.
examples.ja: 天ぷら、唐揚げ、竜田揚げは、どれも食材に衣をつけて揚げる料理です。

examples.en: Tempura uses wheat flour in its batter, karaage uses wheat flour and potato starch, and tatsutaage uses potato starch.
examples.ja: 天ぷらの衣には小麦粉、唐揚げには小麦粉と片栗粉、竜田揚げには片栗粉が使われます。

examples.en: While the seasoning and flour ratios are flexible for karaage, tatsutaage requires a soy sauce-based marinade and potato starch for its batter.
examples.ja: 唐揚げの味付けと粉の比率は自由ですが、竜田揚げには醤油ベースの下味と片栗粉がマストです。

meaning_mnemonic:
You've got a combination of <kanji>China</kanji> and 揚げ, meaning "fried." That makes this Chinese-style <vocabulary>Fried Chicken</vocabulary>, or as you'll probably also know it, <vocabulary>karaage</vocabulary>.

While 唐揚げ most often refers to fried chicken, it can technically also refer to other deep fried meats, fish, or vegetables. As it's the most common meaning, remembering this as "fried chicken" will be just fine, though.
reading_mnemonic:
You know how to read the 揚げ part, but this uses the kun'yomi reading for 唐, which is new. You'll likely be able to remember this reading by associating fried chicken with Japanese karaage, but in case you're not familiar with it, here's a mnemonic to help you:

To make this kind of <vocabulary>fried chicken</vocabulary>, you have to first give it one strong <reading>から</reading>て chop. If you fry it up without that からて chop, it just comes out terrible no matter what you do. So just remember that next time you make it for me, kay?
